fields.info:
Location

Brynglas Farm,
Bryncrug,
Tywyn,
Gwynedd,
LL36 9PY,
Phone: 01654 710 393
  • Satellite photograph
  • Google map

Description

The Brynglas site is a large field on Brynglas farm, very close to the Tal-y-Llyn railway - in fact you have to cross the railway (twice!) as you come through the farm onto the campsite. The campers and officers are all in tents, with the exception of some of the more pampered leaders and chaplains, and the kitchen, toilets and showers are also under canvas. The ample space means that the camps have a nominal capacity of 75, but more can be accommodated.


The camp site provides plenty to do with a large football pitch, volleyball area, small hills to climb, a stream , as well as table tennis and other games in the main marquee. The site, along with the surrounding fields, make it a great place for wide games.

The site is close to Tywyn (a small town with most amenities including a well served railway station) - it only takes 10 minutes by car from camp to Tywyn. The shops there, particularly the honey ice-cream factory, are popular with campers, as well as the leisure centre with its swimming pool. Just past Tywyn is Broadwater, which is a great site for canoing and raft-building. The camp site is also quite close to Cader Idris, which is usually climbed during the course of the week, and also to the picturesque Dolgoch Falls.


Aerial photo

Many thanks to W. Williams. Wynne for this fantastic aerial photograph of the Brynglas site

© W.Williams.Wynne (reproduced with permission).

Llys Andreas Camp Site,
Ffordd Tyddyn Felin
Tal-y-bont
Barmouth
LL43 2AU
Pay phone: 01341 247526
  • Satellite map
  • Google map

This site in Tal-y-bont is used only by the senior camp, and is a smaller site than Tywyn, but still has plenty of room for the 50 campers it can accommodate. It has a main marquee for services and camp-site activities, and a good sized playing space including a volleyball area. There is also a picturesque river just on the edge of the camp-site.

There is a multi-purpose building which houses a kitchen and eating/games areas. The site also has a toilet and wash-block, (including showers) for both males and females.

Llys Andreas is very accessible, just two minutes off the main road between Barmouth & Harlech and just 10 mins from Tal-y-bont railway station. Barmouth also has a leisure centre, which has a five-a-side football pitch, as well a beach, a fair and plenty of shops. There is also a very pleasant beach much closer to Llys Andreas, which is a great spot for barbecues, bathing or bivouacking!

Location

Address (camp time only):

CCIW Camp
Dolgoch
Bryncrug
Tywyn
Gwynedd
LL36 9UW
  • Satellite map
  • Google map

Directions: travelling from Abergynolwyn to Tywyn on the B4405, as the road bends sharply to the right with the Dolgoch Hotel on the left, turn off left into the entrance for the car park. Immediately turn right over a river bridge and go through the gate into the field.

Description

The site is near the beautiful Dolgoch Falls and Dolgoch Falls Hotel, approximately 2 miles from Brynglas. It is a large, flat field, shielded from the road by trees.

The site is equipped with a large main marquee for meetings and fun, as well as a smaller games marquee which is usually used for table tennis.

In this spacious field there is plenty of room for a volleyball pitch, a football pitch and even bigger scale games.

fields.html:
What is camp really about?

Well, there are lots of different answers.

Some will say friendship, and certainly we know of some wonderful friendships formed on camps which have lasted and blossomed over the years, benefiting not only the campers but also the churches to which they belong.

Some will say fun. Well, we certainly do have fun, with something to suit all who have a sense of adventure. Whether it is kayaking, gorge walking, raft building, wide games, bivouacking, table tennis, football, volleyball, camp concerts, tent life, tent inspection, washing up, trips to the coast or even shopping, there is something for everyone. There are optional extras including rock climbing, paint-balling, pony trekking etc.

Whilst friendship and fun are really important, at the heart of camp is a person, Jesus Christ. He makes camp special in so many ways but especially as His gospel is taught and explained in the morning services and tent Bible studies.

The Aim

The aim of the camps is the presentation of the Christian faith to young people in the context of a safe & healthy outdoor camp environment.

Safety and a wholesome environment for campers is paramount. For this reason the teams will be led by experienced leaders and where possible a husband and wife team. Quite often this means that camp life will be enhanced by the presence of young children on site.

The programme varies a bit between the different camps, but will include Bible teaching and/or a tent Bible study every day.

Links

Cheques must be payable to “Christian Camps in Wales”.

However, if you have started the booking process online, please pay online, rather than sending cheques, and contact us if you have any problems. This will save us time - we are all volunteers!

Other camps

If none of these dates work for you, or you would like an indoor option, have a look at the EMW camps.

See also:

  • What is camp all about?
  • Booking and prices
  • Transport to camp
  • Insurance
  • Code of conduct
  • Past camp dates and information

We want everyone to enjoy camp as much as possible and in every way, and these rules will to help ensure this, provided they are followed.

Remember that the rules are for your safety and enjoyment and if you book to come on camp you agree to abide by this code of conduct.

  1. It is expected that everyone will try to join in everything, and maintain acceptable standards of behaviour.
  2. You will be expected to follow the instructions of the leaders and officers at all times, especially during adventure activities. Failure to follow instructions promptly could be dangerous to you and to others.
  3. Under no circumstance are you to go into the tents of the opposite sex. Boys found in girls' tents or vice-versa will be sent home.
  4. Damage or theft of CCIW or other campers' property will not be tolerated.
  5. No alcohol, smoking, drugs etc.
  6. Personal property: no knives other than those used for eating on camp; no personal audio/computer equipment (TV, CD, radio, computer games) is permitted on site.
  7. Mobile phones are permitted but must be switched off during meetings and meals. CCIW does not provide facilities for charging campers' mobile phones.
If you have an enquiry to make, please use the form below and your message will be forwarded to the relevant person, who will reply by e-mail.

Below is the doctrinal basis of CCIW, to which all the directors subscribe and which forms the basis of what we seek to do and teach.

We accept the Holy Scriptures, as originally given, as the infallible Word of God, of divine inspiration. Recognising them as our sole authority in all matters of faith and practice, we believe the doctrines taught therein. In particular we believe:

  1. in the only true and living God, the Holy Trinity of divine Persons in perfect unity, Father, Son and Holy Spirit, each of whom is co-equal and co-eternal, and sovereign in creation, providence and redemption.
  2. in the God and Father of our Lord Jesus Christ, who is holy, righteous, full of grace, mercy, compassion and love. In His infinite love He sent forth the Son, that the world through Him might be saved.
  3. in the Lord Jesus Christ, the incarnate Son of God, whose true humanity and full deity were mysteriously and really joined in the unity of His divine Person. We believe in His virgin birth, in His perfect life and teaching, in His substitutionary, atoning death on the cross, where He triumphed over Satan, sin and death in His bodily resurrection and ascension into heaven, where he now sits in glory at the right hand of God.
  4. in the Holy Spirit, the third Person of the Godhead, whose work is indispensable to regenerate the sinner, to lead him to repentance, to give him faith in Christ, to sanctify the believer in this present life and fit him to enjoy fellowship with God. For spiritual power and effectiveness His ministry is essential to the individual Christian and to the Church.
  5. that as the result of the Fall all men are sinful by nature. Sin pollutes and controls them, infects every part of their being, renders them guilty in the sight of a holy God and subject to the penalty, which in His wrath and condemnation, He has decreed against it.
  6. that through faith (and only faith) in the Lord Jesus Christ, whose death was a perfect oblation and satisfaction for our sins, the sinner is freely justified by God who, instead of reckoning to us our sins, reckons Christs righteousness to our account. Salvation is therefore by grace and not by human merit.
  7. that the Lord Jesus Christ will return personally, visibly, and gloriously to this earth, to receive His saints to Himself and to be seen of all men. As the righteous Judge, He will divide all men into two, and only two, categories - the saved and the lost. Those whose faith is in Christ will be saved eternally, and will enter into the joy of their Lord, sharing with Him His inheritance in heaven. The unbelieving will be condemned by Him to hell where, eternally they will be punished for their sins under the righteous judgement of God.
If you have an enquiry to make, please use the form below and your message will be forwarded to the relevant person, who will reply by e-mail.

CCIW is a volunteer run organisation, with no paid workers. Amazingly, there are lots of Christians who will come and spend a week looking after hundreds of kids on a wet field in Wales, just for the fun of it!

Seriously, serving God through camp work is a great joy and privilege, and there are lots of ways to get involved. The main roles are:

  • Leaders and officers - people who spend a week on site looking after campers in some way.
  • Site helpers - those who help to put up and take down the camp sites.
  • CCIW committee/directors - overall responsibility for CCIW.

Newsletter

A vital way you can support our work is by praying for it. If you would like to be kept in touch with CCIW activities via our email newsletter, please sign up below.

If you have forgotten your username or password, you get a new password or a reminder of your username sent to you by e-mail. For the new password, you will have to follow the instructions in the e-mail in order to activate the new password (it's very simple -- just clicking a link). Please enter your e-mail address below and choose from the options.

The details vary from camp to camp, but all of them include worship services together, activities in the afternoon and bible studies in tent groups. The kind of activities we do include canoeing, raft-building, swimming, walking, rock-climbing, and gorge-walking, as well as football, rounders and other camp site games. Below is a list of other pages to find out more about the camps.

Contents:

  • Coronavirus update - latest information here.

  • Camps 2020
    Although we couldn't run camps this year, the leaders of each camp have prepared a video message for you.

  • Camps {{thisyear}}

    Find out what our camps are like and what they are really for.

  • Camp sites
    Information on the different sites we run camps at.

  • Helpers
    We always need people to help run camp! We have a particular need for volunteers to help set up and take down our camp sites.

  • Past camp information

  • About CCiW
    Company information, including the doctrinal basis of CCiW, legal information, and the names and addresses of the directors.

  • Contact us
    Any comments about camp, suggestions, or other reasons to get in contact with us - leave us a message.

  • Officer area
    Section of website for those who are already officers.

Subscribe to our mailing list

We use a third party email service provider, MailChimp, to send you these newsletter emails. We provide MailChimp with only your email address. MailChimp treats information about you in accordance with the provisions of its Privacy Policy. MailChimp also utilizes certain technologies, such as pixels and web beacons, in the emails that are sent through MailChimp. These technologies allow MailChimp to track whether you have opened or clicked on our emails and if so, the date, time, and IP address associated with the open and/or click. For more information on MailChimp's use of these technologies, you can read their Cookie Statement.

• What is camp all about?
  • Directors
  • Doctrinal basis
  • Legal information

Policies

We have various polices to cover the nature of the camps. To find out more information please get in touch.

Activities

CCiW run a range of activities ourselves and uses a range of licensed providers. Should you want more information about the ones we use, please contact us.

Child protection

At CCiW we take protection of children in our care extremely seriously. If you need to contact our Child Protection Officer about our policies, or to report abuse, please email cpo@cciw.co.uk.

You may also wish to report abuse to the governments Child Exploitation and Online Protection Centre.

Insurance

Many people ask about insurance on camp.

Insurance for camps like this falls into 2 basic categories:

  1. Public Liability
  2. Personal Accident cover

Public Liability is a cover which provides protection for campers should they have an accident which was due to the negligence of CCiW or any of the camp leaders or officers. This sort of insurance also provides 3rd party cover for the camp for situations where we may be liable for damage incurred by people not connected with the camp. Standard cover up to £1,000,000 is provided.

If anyone should want to see this policy it will be available on camp.

Personal Accident cover is a "no-blame" type of insurance which will pay out in the case of injury even if it is a simple accident. i.e. no blame attached.

CCiW does not provide this type of insurance cover but if you wish to have it tick the relevant question on the Booking Form and we will send you information for you to obtain your own cover.

Also, note that insurance for adventure activities is provided by the Licensed Activity Provider.

Our insurance company is Ansvar Ltd.

Paper booking form

There is no booking form for {{thisyear}} available yet online. Booking forms are normally printed in January, and are distributed to all individuals who came on camp the previous year (sometimes via churches). We try to make the booking form available online as a PDF file at about the same time, so that you can print your own.

An item will be added on the news page when the booking form is available for download.

If you would like a booking form sent in the post and are not on our distribution list (or have not received a booking form and think you should have), please use the feedback form to request one. Please remember to to include your address so that we can post one. If you are ordering a large number of booking forms, please include your telephone number so that we can verify the request.

Being an officer on camp can involve a variety of things:

  • Looking after campers as a tent officer
  • Leading Bible studies
  • Helping in the kitchen
  • Playing games and running outdoor activities
  • Helping to maintain the site

Most officers will do a few of the above, but not many will do all of them - it depends on your abilities and experience!

Each camp has a few leaders who are the officers in overall charge for that camp.

Because we are a Christian organisation and take the care of campers very seriously, including their spiritual and physical well-being, we are very careful about who we ask to be officers on camp. In general it should be understood that being an officer on camp is by invitation only, and normally you will need to be in contact with one of the leaders of the camps if you want to come on camp. You will also need to complete an application form, which includes providing the names of referees, and agree to Criminal Records Bureau/Disclosure and Barring Service checks.

If you do not know leaders of camps personally, but would like to offer your services, please use the contact form to send us a message.

Officer facilities on the website

Once you have been invited on camp by one of the leaders, you will be given a login name for the officer area, and can then proceed to the officer facilities of this website. Please note that this has a completely separate login system to the bookings.

Setting up and taking down the camp sites (especially Brynglas Farm and Dolgoch) are big jobs, and we always appreciate any help we can get.

For each site, both set up and take down take about a week each, and is usually done by a small team of volunteers, some of whom are there for the whole week, others for just a day. While it is hard work, it is also very enjoyable, and a perfect opportunity to enjoy some Welsh weather (for better or worse!) in a beautiful valley, serving the gospel and the work of the CCIW camps - without dealing with any campers!

As well as fairly long days of hard work, we make time for enjoying Christian fellowship and meals together, and usually come away with a tan.

There are typically 4 weeks of set up/take down over the summer, which depend on the dates of the camps. Please contact us if you would like to be involved.

If you are already part of the team, you should have access to the camp wiki where there is a lot more information about details.

Google map showing all sites:


View CCIW camp sites in a larger map

Please consult the maps and locations of our camp sites to arrange your transport.

The nearest public train station local to both Brynglas and Dolgoch camp sites is Tywyn. If you require collecting from Tywyn Rail Station, please inform your camp leaders before camp so that a minibus to the camp site can be arranged for you.

In the past, we have provided some long-distance transport to camp in the form of minibuses from South Wales, but this is no longer available.

On this site, you can find:

  • Full message board system, a board for every camp, where each board can have multiple threads (topics).
  • Photo galleries, where you can also add your own comments.
  • Private messaging - send messages direct to other users, including the option to receive messages by e-mail.
  • User settings - customise your preferences, including a spot to put some details in about yourself and upload a personal icon.

Requirements

  • This website is designed for any web browser. It looks best in browsers that have good CSS support.
  • Cookies are required to be able to log in as a user.
  • Some features require javascript. These include:
    • The integrated bible passage lookup
    • Clickable emoticons in messages

More info

  • Reporting problems
  • General help pages
  • Help forum
  • Terms of service

Something isn't working on the site. How do I report it?

If there was a problem on the site, you can send the webmaster a message about it. Answers to commonly asked questions will be added below.

What happened to the forums and galleries?

Since they had not been in use since about 2007, the forums and galleries have been removed. You may be able to find archived copies on The Internet Archive.

Related links

  • Terms of service

By using this website, you agree to abide by the following terms and conditions.

Purposes of the web site

This web site is intended for people who have been on CCIW camps, those interested in doing so, and their friends. It has the following purposes:

  1. To provide information about CCIW and the camps it runs to all those interested in attending
  2. To provide a friendly, fun, safe, healthy environment in which those who have attended camps can continue their friendships and encourage each other to love the Lord Jesus Christ.

Principles

When using the message boards and private messages, the following principles must be remembered:

  1. Colossians 4:6 "Let your conversation be always full of grace, seasoned with salt, so that you may know how to answer everyone".
  2. Romans 12:17,18 "Do not repay evil for evil. Be careful to do what is right in the eyes of everybody. If it is possible, as far as it depends on you, live at peace with everyone."
  3. Hebrews 13:17 "Obey your leaders and submit to their authority. They keep watch over you as men who must give an account. Obey them so that their work will be a joy, not a burden, for that would be of no advantage to you."

    Although that is written for a church context, the logic applies to this situation, where those in authority are the moderators and web site administrators.

Any use of this web site in ways which contradict or hinder the purposes and principles above is not allowed. More explicitly:

Rules

  1. All users of the web site must be shown respect, and attacks on others will not be tolerated.
  2. Crude language and blasphemy (taking God's name lightly) are forbidden.
  3. Use of the message boards for advertising unrelated or inappropriate web sites is not allowed.
  4. Moderators may remove or modify messages, and their decision is final.
  5. Usernames not appropriate for a Christian are not allowed.

If these rules are ignored the web site admins may limit the privileges of a user or ban them entirely.

Privacy policy

To sign up as a member, you must provide an e-mail address. This e-mail address will never be given to any third party. It may very occasionally be used to e-mail all signed up members with important information, or to e-mail an individual user with regard to their use of the web site.

By default your e-mail address is not visible to other users. You can opt to have it visible, and in this case it will be displayed in a manner that makes it virtually 'spam proof', so that the e-mail address will not be collected by spammers from this site. (Spammers are known to have programs that trawl web sites for e-mail addresses)

Every effort will be taken to ensure that e-mail addresses are not made visible without your consent, but due to the fact that other people and systems are involved we cannot guarantee that this information will remain private.

All other content contributed to the site is publically visible, and it is the responsiblity of the individual users to take any necessary precautions with regard to anything posted on the site. Also, we cannot gaurantee the confidentiality of private messages sent using the site.

Disclaimer

The services on this web site are provided for free, and there is therefore no warranty or guarantee for any part of them. Use of this web site is at your own risk, and CCIW shall in no event be liable for any damages incurred through use of this site.

Since your ISP probably uses some type of spam filter we ask that you add us to your trusted list of senders, contacts or address book. This is also known as whitelisting.

If you do not see an email from CCIW website in your inbox, due to the overzealous filtering by ISPs, our email may have mistakenly been sent to your spam folder. Please open your spam folder look for it there, open it and mark it as "not spam"...

Choose from the options below for help in whiltelisting email from CCIW website.

ISPs AOL, AOL Web Mail, Yahoo, Hotmail Live, Windows Live and MSN, Gmail, Earthlink, AT&T, Comcast

Email Clients: Outlook 2003 (or higher), Mozilla Thunderbird, Blackberrys,

Spam Filters: Norton AntiSpam, McAfee Spamkiller, Barracuda Networks, Trend Micro PC-Cillin, Cloudmark SpamNet, CA Anti Spam, Mailblocks, MailShield, MailWasher, Oddpost, SpamAssassin, SpamFighter, ChoiceMail, SpamButcher, Spameater Pro Spam Inspector, Spam Interceptor, SpamPal, Spam Sleuth, Other providers:

If you use Spam Arrest or other challenge response spam filter please whitelist CCIW website.

AOL back to top

To make sure email gets delivered to your AOL inbox, you must add the email address or corporate domain of the sender to your Address Book or Custom Sender List.

  1. Click the "Spam Controls" link on the lower right side of your inbox screen.
  2. When the "Mail & Spam Controls" box appears, click the "Custom sender list" link.
  3. Choose the "allow email from noreply@cciw.co.uk" option.
  4. Add the domain or email address you would like to receive mail from, then click "Add"
  5. Click "Save"

AOL Web Mail back to top

If using AOL web mail replying to an email from CCIW website will also work.

Email from that domain will now be delivered straight to your Inbox.

Yahoo! Mail back to top

If you're not receiving email you are expecting, there are two things you can do:

  1. Use the "Not Spam" button in your Bulk folder.
  2. Create a filter to automatically send email from certain domains to your Inbox. This is the only way to really ensure delivery.

Report as "Not Spam"

  1. - Check your Yahoo! Bulk folder
  2. - If you see the email from CCIW website, highlight it and click "Not Spam"
  3. - This does not guarantee that your mail will be delivered in the future, but it does help.

Create a Filter

  1. Click "Options" in the top right navigation bar
  2. Select "Mail Options" from the list that drops down
  3. Choose "Filters" located on the left side of the page
  4. Click the "Add" button on the Filters page
  5. Choose the field you want to match in the incoming message. For example, "header" or "to".
  6. Choose the criterion by which you want a match to be made, such as "contains"
  7. Enter the text string to compare. For example: from CCIW website
  8. Choose the destination folder to which you would like the message delivered. For example: Inbox

Hotmail Live, Windows Live and MSN back to top

In the new Hotmail you must "Mark sender as safe" to enable hyperlinks even in text emails and images in HTML emails.

Entering the email contact in the address book or contacts no longer whitelists the sender

To ensure messages from specific email addresses are not sent to your Junk Email folder, you can do one of two things:

  1. Check the "Junk" folder if you do not see our email in your inbox
  2. Click the "Mark as safe" link
  3. Add noreply@cciw.co.uk to your Safe List

    4. Mark Sender as Safe

    Attachments, pictures, and links in this message have been blocked for your safety. Show content

    CCIW website noreply@cciw.co.uk

    From: noreply@cciw.co.uk     You may not know this sender. Mark as safe | Mark as unsafe
    Sent: Thu 6/14/07 12:00 AM
    Reply-to: noreply@cciw.co.uk

  1. Click "Show content" to view the body of the email if it contains images and HTML
  2. Click "Mark as safe"
  3. CCIW website will now be added to your list of "Safe senders"

Manually Add to Safe List

  1. Click "Options" in the upper right corner of your Hotmail screen
  2. In the Body of the page under "Junk e-mail" click the link "Safe and blocked senders"
  3. Click the link "Safe senders"
  4. Enter the email address "noreply@cciw.co.uk"
  5. Click "Add to list"

Gmail back to top

To make sure email gets delivered to your inbox, you must add the email address noreply@cciw.co.uk to your contacts list.

  1. Click the drop down arrow next to "Reply" in the upper right side of your inbox screen.
  2. Click the "Add CCIW website to Contacts List" from the list that appears.
  3. You will now see CCIW website appear under the link "Contacts" on the left side of the page.
  4. Click the link "Contacts" and the in the "Search Contacts" form field.
  5. Now you can select to move CCIW website to a contact list of choice and edit any details.

Outlook 2003 (or higher) back to top

Because of the various email platforms that can work with Outlook, it is tricky to tell you how to recieve all email to your Outlook inbox. We can tell you, however, how to make sure you can see all the emails you receive as they were intended to be seen - with images. If a company is not in your address book or "Safe Sender" list, your HTML images will not display.

To have HTML display correctly, users can:

  • Change their automatic download settings
  • Add sender to your address book
  • Add your email or domain to their approved sender list

To change settings:

  1. Right click on a non-displaying image in an HTML email
  2. Choose "Change automatic download settings" option
  3. When the popup comes up, uncheck the first box in the list that says "donï¿½t download pictures or other HTML content automatically
  4. Click "OK"

To add sender to address book:

  1. Open the email
  2. Right click on the from address
  3. Choose "Add to contacts" option

To add domain to safe sender list:

  1. Right click on a non-displaying image in an HTML email
  2. Choose "Add the domain to the safe sender list" option

Earthlink back to top

If you are not receiving email at Earthlink, there are two actions you can take.

  1. Check "Suspect Email" folder
  2. Add to your address book

With Earthlink, if you have SpamBlocker turned on, suspect messages are automatically send to your Suspect Email folder if the domain is not in your address book.

Suspect Email Folder

  1. While in the "Suspect Email" folder, if you see CCIW website...
  2. Select the "Move to Inbox and Add Contact" option from the pull down menu.
  3. This will add noreply@cciw.co.uk to your Address Book for future email delivery assurance.

Address Book Inclusion

  1. Open the email.
  2. Click "Add to Address Book" in the email header.
  3. Use the "Address Book Editor" to verify the sender's contact details and click "save."
  4. Fill in noreply@cciw.co.uk as the email address of the sender.
  5. Any mail sent with the same domain (right of the @ sign) will now be delivered to your Inbox.

AT&T back to top

  1. Open the email message from the sender you want to add to your address book.
  2. Click on the "Save Address" link (below) next to the "From Address.
  3. Check the "Add to Contacts" box (below) and click "Save.

Comcast back to top

  1. Click on the [Save Address]   link at the top of this message (it's next to From Address).
  2. For the field titled First Name, please enter CCIW website
  3. Then click Save Entry and you're all done.

BlackBerrys back to top

  1. Scroll up to the message header
  2. Get to the field where noreply@cciw.co.uk is listed, click the Berry button and then click Show Address
  3. Click the Berry button and then click Add to contacts

Mozilla Thunderbird back to top

  1. Click the Address Book button
  2. Make sure the Personal Address Book is highlighted
  3. Click the New Card button. This will launch a New Card window that has 3 tabs: Contact, Address and Other
  4. Under the Contact tab, copy and paste the "From" address, noreply@cciw.co.uk into the email dialogue box
  5. Click OK

Norton AntiSpam back to top

  1. Start up Norton AntiSpam
  2. Click the Status & Settings tab
  3. Click AntiSpam
  4. Click Configure
  5. Click Allowed List tab
  6. Click Add button
  7. In the 'Email Address' box, enter noreply@cciw.co.uk
  8. Click OK
  9. Click OK

Trend Micro back to top

If you received an email message that was incorrectly moved to the Spam Mail folder by the Anti-Spam Toolbar you can prevent this from occuring in the future.

The Anti-Spam Toolbar detects spam by looking for certain keywords in the email's subject or body and matching it with the anti-spam pattern file. Occasionally, it may detect what you consider legitimate email as spam.

To prevent this from occurring you can do either of the following:

  • Add the sender to the list of Approved Senders
  • Decrease the Spam Email Filter Strength

Note: You can also select the email and click Not Spam to report it to Trend Micro. However, this feature serves only as a reference when we develop our spam database, and it may not have an effect on how the toolbar detects spam.

Add the sender to the list of Approved Senders

  1. Open Microsoft Outlook or Outlook Express.
  2. Click the Spam Mail folder then select the legitimate email detected as spam.
  3. Click Approve Sender on the toolbar.
  4. Click Yes when the confirmation message appears.

Decrease the Spam Email Filter Strength

  1. Open Microsoft Outlook or Outlook Express.
  2. Click Trend Micro Anti-Spam then click Settings.
  3. On the Spam Filter tab, move the slider bar to select a lower filter strength.
  4. Click OK to save your settings.

McAfee Spamkiller back to top

  1. Select Friends from the McAfee SpamKiller sidebar.
  2. Click Add a friend.
  3. Make sure All users at a domain is selected under Friend type:
  4. Type the domain name you want to whitelist under Address:
  5. To whitelist all our newsletters, type
  6. Optionally, enter a CCIW website to help you recognize the domain under Name:
  7. Click OK.
  8. Click OK.

Barracuda Networks back to top

The Barracuda Spam Firewall is a popular spam filtering solution. Barracuda uses several algorithms and processes to determine whether emails are spam. Occasionally, it will mark a legitimate message as spam. There are two methods to whitelist email senders so that the firewall will not quarantine future email.

Whitelist Quarantined Senders

  1. Open your email client. Barracuda should send you a summary each day listing quarantined items. Choose the most recent Barracuda email message.
  2. Locate the email from CCIW website and the sender email address noreply@cciw.co.uk that you do not want quarantined in the future. Click on the word "Whitelist," which is in green print to the right of the email title. This will open your list in a web browser.
  3. Click the box to the left of the email that you would like to whitelist. At the top of the page, click "Whitelist." Barracuda will not block or quarantine the sender whose email address appears on the whitelist.

Whitelist Senders and Domains

  1. Open your web browser. Navigate to your company's Barracuda firewall homepage.
  3. Click on the "Block/Accept" tab.
  4. Choose "Sender Domain Block/Accept." Enter the domain name from noreply@cciw.co.uk to whitelist. For example, you can enter aol.com to allow all AOL addresses. You may enter a comment to remind you why you allowed this domain. Click "Add."
  5. Click your mouse on the "Email Sender Block/Accept" tab. Enter the email address of an individual sender that you want to whitelist, such as "noreply@cciw.co.uk" Include a comment. Click "Add." In the future, Barracuda will not block emails from this sender.

Cloudmark SpamNet back to top

  1. Select Cloudmark | Options... from the Cloudmark SpamNet toolbar in Outlook.
  2. Click Advanced.
  3. Go to the Whitelist tab.
  4. Click the Add button.
  5. Type: noreply@cciw.co.uk
  6. Click OK.
  7. Click OK.
  8. Click Yes.
  9. Click OK.

Mailblocks back to top

  1. Click the Addresses tab.
  2. Click New.
  3. Type: noreply@cciw.co.uk
  4. Make sure 'Accept Mail From This Address' is selected under Receiving Options.
  5. Uncheck 'Display in People Picker' under Other options.
  6. Click Submit.
  7. Click OK.

MailShield back to top

  1. Click Friends from the toolbar.
  2. Click Add.
  3. Type: noreply@cciw.co.uk
  4. Click OK.

MailWasher back to top

  1. Click Tools, then Blacklist & Friends.
  2. Click Add... on the right, the Friends list side.
  3. Make sure Plain email address is selected.
  4. Type: noreply@cciw.co.uk
  5. Click OK.
  6. Click OK.

Oddpost back to top

  1. Check your 'Probably Spam' folder.
  2. If you see that our email was incorrectly filtered out
  3. Select it
    4. Click the 'Move to Inbox and Mark as Not Spam' button.

SpamAssassin back to top

  1. Add the following entry to your user_prefs file, which is found in the .spamassassin subdirectory on your web/mail server
  2. whitelist_from noreply@cciw.co.uk
  3. Save the user_prefs file or move the updated copy to your .spamassassin subdirectory.

SPAMfighter back to top

Highlight the email from CCIW website with the email address noreply@cciw.co.uk to Whitelist.

Click "More" in the SPAMfighter Toolbar and select "Whitelist".

Here you can choose if you want to Whitelist the email address noreply@cciw.co.uk or the whole domain.

To be sure that all emails from people in your Outlook contacts get through to you, you can import and Whitelist them.

To do this, follow these steps:

  1. Click "More" in the SPAMfighter toolbar.
  2. Then "Options"
  3. Then "Filter settings"
  4. Then "Blacklists & Whitelists"
  5. Then "Whitelist email address"
  6. Then "Import".
  7. Select your 'Address Book' and click on "Check all"
  8. Click "Add"
  9. Click "Apply"

If you get a pop-up box offering you to upgrade to SPAMfighter Pro it is because you have exceeded the limit of 100 addresses. You can fix this by buying SPAMfighter Pro or by deleting some of the addresses in your Black/White list. If you want delete addresses, please go to:

  1. Click More" in the SPAMfighter toolbar.
  2. Then "Options"
  3. Then "Filter settings"
  4. Then "Blacklists & Whitelists"

ChoiceMail back to top

  1. Open ChoiceMail
  2. Click on the Senders tab
  3. Choose "Approve another Sender"
  4. Type in the sender email address noreply@cciw.co.uk
  5. Click on OK

SpamButcher back to top

  1. Click the Configure button.
  2. Go to the Known Senders tab.
  3. Click Add under 'Known Good Senders and Recipients'.
  4. Type: noreply@cciw.co.uk
  5. Click OK.
  6. Click OK.

Spameater Pro back to top

  1. Click Filters from the sidebar.
  2. Click the Approved Senders tab.
  3. Click Add Filter.
  4. Type: noreply@cciw.co.uk under Address.
  5. Choose 'Full Email Address' under Address Type.
  6. Select Email Domain.
  7. Click OK.

Spam Inspector back to top

  1. Select Spam Inspector
  2. Then 'Manage Friends List' from either the Spam Inspector toolbar or from the Outlook menu.
  3. Make sure Email is selected under 'Add a New Friend'.
  4. Type: noreply@cciw.co.uk
  5. Click the >> button.
  6. Click Close.

Spam Interceptor back to top

  1. Follow the Trusted link under > Authentication Lists.
  2. Enter the email address: noreply@cciw.co.uk
  3. Click Add.

SpamPal back to top

  1. Click on the SpamPal system tray icon with the right mouse button.
  2. Click 'Add to Whitelist' from the menu.
  3. Type: noreply@cciw.co.uk
  4. Click Add.

Spam Sleuth back to top

  1. Select File, then Configure.
  2. Go to the Friends category.
  3. Make sure Active is checked.
  4. Type: noreply@cciw.co.uk on a line by itself in the entry field.
  5. Click OK.

Other Spam Filters Not List Above.... back to top

If our email is being filtered, try adding noreply@cciw.co.uk to your Address Book or Contact list.

If messages continue to be sent to your junk folder contact your ISP or spam filter application support and ask how to whitelist noreply@cciw.co.uk.

Since your ISP probably uses some type of spam filter we ask that you add us to your trusted list of senders, contacts or address book. This is also known as whitelisting.

If you do not see an email from CCIW lists in your inbox, due to the overzealous filtering by ISPs our email may have mistakenly been sent to your spam folder. Please open your spam folder look for it there, open it and mark it as "not spam"...

Choose from the options below for help in whiltelisting email from CCIW website.

ISPs AOL, AOL Web Mail, Yahoo, Hotmail Live, Windows Live and MSN, Gmail, Earthlink, AT&T, Comcast

Email Clients: Outlook 2003 (or higher), Mozilla Thunderbird, Blackberrys,

Spam Filters: Norton AntiSpam, McAfee Spamkiller, Barracuda Networks, Trend Micro PC-Cillin, Cloudmark SpamNet, CA Anti Spam, Mailblocks, MailShield, MailWasher, Oddpost, SpamAssassin, SpamFighter, ChoiceMail, SpamButcher, Spameater Pro Spam Inspector, Spam Interceptor, SpamPal, Spam Sleuth, Other providers:

If you use Spam Arrest or other challenge response spam filter please whitelist CCIW lists.

AOL back to top

To make sure email gets delivered to your AOL inbox, you must add the email address or corporate domain of the sender to your Address Book or Custom Sender List.

  1. Click the "Spam Controls" link on the lower right side of your inbox screen.
  2. When the "Mail & Spam Controls" box appears, click the "Custom sender list" link.
  3. Choose the "allow email from lists@cciw.co.uk" option.
  4. Add the domain or email address you would like to receive mail from, then click "Add"
  5. Click "Save"

AOL Web Mail back to top

If using AOL web mail replying to an email from CCIW lists will also work.

Email from that domain will now be delivered straight to your Inbox.

Yahoo! Mail back to top

If youï¿½re not receiving email you are expecting, there are two things you can do:

  1. Use the "Not Spam" button in your Bulk folder.
  2. Create a filter to automatically send email from certain domains to your Inbox. This is the only way to really ensure delivery.

Report as "Not Spam"

  1. - Check your Yahoo! Bulk folder
  2. - If you see the email from CCIW lists, highlight it and click "Not Spam"
  3. - This does not guarantee that your mail will be delivered in the future, but it does help.

Create a Filter

  1. Click "Options" in the top right navigation bar
  2. Select "Mail Options" from the list that drops down
  3. Choose "Filters" located on the left side of the page
  4. Click the "Add" button on the Filters page
  5. Choose the field you want to match in the incoming message. For example, "header" or "to".
  6. Choose the criterion by which you want a match to be made, such as "contains"
  7. Enter the text string to compare. For example: from CCIW lists
  8. Choose the destination folder to which you would like the message delivered. For example: Inbox

Hotmail Live, Windows Live and MSN back to top

In the new Hotmail you must "Mark sender as safe" to enable hyperlinks even in text emails and images in HTML emails.

Entering the email contact in the address book or contacts no longer whitelists the sender

To ensure messages from specific email addresses are not sent to your Junk Email folder, you can do one of two things:

  1. Check the "Junk" folder if you do not see the our email in your inbox
  2. Click the "Mark as safe" link
  3. Add lists@cciw.co.uk to your Safe List

    4. Mark Sender as Safe

    Attachments, pictures, and links in this message have been blocked for your safety. Show content

    CCIW lists lists@cciw.co.uk

    From: lists@cciw.co.uk     You may not know this sender. Mark as safe | Mark as unsafe
    Sent: Thu 6/14/07 12:00 AM
    Reply-to: lists@cciw.co.uk

  1. Click "Show content" to view the body of the email if it contains images and HTML
  2. Click "Mark as safe"
  3. CCIW lists will now be added to your list of "Safe senders"

Manually Add to Safe List

  1. Click "Options" in the upper right corner of your Hotmail screen
  2. In the Body of the page under "Junk e-mail" click the link "Safe and blocked senders"
  3. Click the link "Safe senders"
  4. Enter the email address "lists@cciw.co.uk"
  5. Click "Add to list"

Gmail back to top

To make sure email gets delivered to your inbox, you must add the email address lists@cciw.co.uk to your contacts list.

  1. Click the drop down arrow next to "Reply" in the upper right side of your inbox screen.
  2. Click the "Add CCIW lists to Contacts List" from the list that appears.
  3. You will now see CCIW lists appear under the link "Contacts" on the left side of the page.
  4. Click the link "Contacts" and the in the "Search Contacts" form field.
  5. Now you can select to move CCIW lists to a contact list of choice and edit any details.

Outlook 2003 (or higher) back to top

Because of the various email platforms that can work with Outlook, it is tricky to tell you how to recieve all email to your Outlook inbox. We can tell you, however, how to make sure you can see all the emails you receive as they were intended to be seen - with images. If a company is not in your address book or "Safe Sender" list, your HTML images will not display.

To have HTML display correctly, users can:

  • Change their automatic download settings
  • Add sender to your address book
  • Add your email or domain to their approved sender list

To change settings:

  1. Right click on a non-displaying image in an HTML email
  2. Choose "Change automatic download settings" option
  3. When the popup comes up, uncheck the first box in the list that says "donï¿½t download pictures or other HTML content automatically
  4. Click "OK"

To add sender to address book:

  1. Open the email
  2. Right click on the from address
  3. Choose "Add to contacts" option

To add domain to safe sender list:

  1. Right click on a non-displaying image in an HTML email
  2. Choose "Add the domain to the safe sender list" option

Earthlink back to top

If you are not receiving email at Earthlink, there are two actions you can take.

  1. Check "Suspect Email" folder
  2. Add to your address book

With Earthlink, if you have SpamBlocker turned on, suspect messages are automatically send to your Suspect Email folder if the domain is not in your address book.

Suspect Email Folder

  1. While in the "Suspect Email" folder, if you see CCIW lists...
  2. Select the "Move to Inbox and Add Contact" option from the pull down menu.
  3. This will add lists@cciw.co.uk to your Address Book for future email delivery assurance.

Address Book Inclusion

  1. Open the email.
  2. Click "Add to Address Book" in the email header.
  3. Use the "Address Book Editor" to verify the sender's contact details and click "save."
  4. Fill in lists@cciw.co.uk as the email address of the sender.
  5. Any mail sent with the same domain (right of the @ sign) will now be delivered to your Inbox.

AT&T back to top

  2. Click on the "Save Address" link (below) next to the "From Address.
  3. Check the "Add to Contacts" box (below) and click "Save.

Comcast back to top

  1. Click on the [Save Address]   link at the top of this message (it's next to From Address).
  2. For the field titled First Name, please enter CCIW lists
  3. Then click Save Entry and you're all done.

BlackBerrys back to top

Generate you own whitelist instructions here...

fields.name: Rev Norman Gilbert
fields.info: Norman Gilbert has been pastor of Cosheston Mission near Pembroke for a number of years. He was Chaplain on this camp for the first time in 2000.

fields.name: Rob & Jane Plant
fields.info: Rob and Jane have been leading camps similar to this one for over 20 years. Rob is an elder in Christ Church, Bradford (was 'Pollard Park Evangelical Church') and he is an Engineering Manager. Jane is first of all a mother to their 5 children all of whom have been coming to camp since they were a few months old. In addition Jane works in a Christian school.

fields.name: Rev John Woolley
fields.info: John, along with his wife Deborah, have been involved with camps (either EMW or CCIW) since the early 1990's. He has been in pastoral work since shortly after that time, most recently as pastor at Emmanuel Baptist, Cardiff. He is an ex- PE teacher, who for many years has been involved with youth work and Boys' Brigade. John and Deborah have four children.

fields.name: Jason & Ruth Phillips
fields.info: Jason and Ruth Phillips are members at Highfields Free Church Cardiff. They have been involved with camps for a number of years as an officers and leaders. Jason is a maths teacher.

fields.name: David & Alyson Turner
fields.info: David and Alyson are members at Bridgend Evangelical Church.

fields.name: Mervyn Neal
fields.info: Merv has been married to Kim for 30 years.  He came to Christ 25 years ago in Lincolnshire. He studied at West and then pastored in Swansea and Barry for 20 years. Merv and Kim have been working full time on the missions field for last three years including training village pastors and church planters. Their two daughters and one grandson live in Wales.

fields.name: Matthew & Helen Jones
fields.info: Matthew and Helen Jones attend Wall Heath Evangelical Free Church in the West Midlands.

fields.name: Rev Gwynne Evans
fields.info: Gwynne Evans and his wife have been leading camps similar to this one for many years. Gwynne is currently the Pastor of Hayes Town Chapel. Before that he was the pastor of an Evangelical church in Droylsden for many years.

fields.name: Jonny & Rachel Pearse
fields.info: Jonny and Rachel live in Southport, where Jonny works at Grace Baptist Church Southport. They have been officers on many camps and have been part of the leadership of all the CCIW senior camps so far.  They have four children.

fields.name: Rev Gary Benfold
fields.info: Gary is the pastor of Moordown Baptist Church in Bournemouth. He has been a Chaplain on many camps, including a number together with Jonathan and Rachel.

fields.name: Jonny Pearse
fields.info: Jonny led camps with his wife Rachel for many years, and was chaplain for the first time in 2004.  He works at Grace Baptist Church Southport as co-pastor.

fields.name: Dave & Rebecca Stott
fields.info: Dave and Rebecca are members of Upton Baptist Church, Chester.  Dave has been a leader or assistant leader on many camps (EMW, CCIW and church camps).

fields.name: John Richards
fields.info: John is a staff worker with Universities and Colleges Christian Fellowship and is based in North Wales. He is married to Katherine and they have a baby girl called Erin. John has helped on camps since 1994

fields.name: Rose Rees
fields.info: Rose is a qualified doctor at Prince Charles Hospital Merthyr Tydfil. She is married to Matthew who is a Licensed Activity Provider for CCIW.

fields.name: Rev David Finnie
fields.info: David is the minister of Ebenezer Evangelical Church Bangor North Wales. He has been the minister at Ebenzer since 1997. He is married to Kyung-Ju from Korea and they have two children aged 6 and 2. This the first time for David to be Chaplain on camp.

fields.name: Rev Gerrard Perry
fields.info: n/a

fields.name: Colin Davies
fields.info: n/a

fields.name: David & Rosalind Williams
fields.info: n/a

fields.name: Kim Neal
fields.info: n/a

fields.name: Rev Bryan Jones
fields.info: n/a

fields.name: Rev Al Simms
fields.info: Rev Alistair Simms is Co-Minister at Wem Baptist Church. He has been coming on CCIW camps with his wife Gill and their family since 2007.

fields.name: Ralph Hammond
fields.info: Ralph Hammond is from Penzance Baptist Church, Cornwall, and has been coming on camps as a camper and leader for many years, leading for the first time in 2007.

fields.name: Fiona Upchurch
fields.info: Fiona loves the outdoors is a member at Trinity Church, Exeter, she is married to Nathan and they have two daughters, Jess and Arabella aged 6 and 5. We try to be outside lots as a family and love to see some of God's character through creation.

fields.name: Matthew Harris
fields.info: Matthew Harris is a member of Woodgreen Evangelical Church, Worcester.  He is a policeman and has been an officer on camp for a number of years with Phil & Liz Vellacott.

fields.name: Allison Huckeridge
fields.info: Allison Huckeridge is a member of Woodgreen Evangelical Church, Worcester.  She is a teacher and has been an officer on camp for a number of years with Phil & Liz Vellacott.

fields.name: Ed & Theresa McMillen
fields.info: Ed and Theresa are from Myton Church in Warwick, where Ed is the minister.

fields.name: Matthew Jones
fields.info: Matthew Jones is the Pastor at Wall Heath Evangelical Free Church in the West Midlands.

fields.name: Andy & Carolyn Glennie
fields.info: Andy and Carolyn are members in Mount Zion Baptist Church, Cardigan, West Wales.

fields.name: Adrian & Ruth Tickle
fields.info: Adrian and Ruth are members of Grace Baptist Church Port Erin, Isle of Man. They both attended camps as campers and have been back as helpers for many years. They have 2 little boys who also love to attend camp!

fields.name: Levon Chorbadjian
fields.info: Levon is a member of Heath Evangelical Church in Cardiff.

fields.name: Nikki Spouse
fields.info: Nikki is a member of Caersalem Baptist Church in Cardiff.

fields.name: Darren & Ali Smith
fields.info: Darren and Ali live in Lincoln, where they are members of Lincoln Evangelical Church. They have two children, Ben and Phoebe, who are regulars on camp. They were assistant leaders with Rob & Jane Plant for many years before taking over as leaders.

fields.name: Dave Stott
fields.info: Dave is a Associate Pastor at Upton Baptist Church, Chester. Dave has been a leader or assistant leader on many camps (EMW, CCIW and church camps), usually with his wife Rebecca.

fields.name: Rachel Pearse
fields.info: Rachel is a member of Moordown Baptist Church, Bournemouth. She was an officer on junior camps and has led senior camps, usually with her husband Jon.

fields.name: Lois Booker
fields.info: Lois is a member of Mount Pleasant Baptist Church in Swansea.

fields.name: Andrew & Katherine Close
fields.info: Andrew and Katherine Close attend Caerwent Evangelical Baptist Chapel in South East Wales. They have two boys aged 9 and 6.

fields.name: Ed McMillen
fields.info: Ed is the Minister at Myton Church in Warwick. He has also led CCiW camps with his wife Theresa.

fields.name: Paul Whiteley
fields.info: Paul Whiteley is the Pastor of Penyrheol Community Church, Gorseinon

fields.name: Andy Cole
fields.info: Andy is the Senior Pastor of Monyhull Church, Birmingham. He is married to Julia, and they have two children, Elijah and Abigail.

fields.name: Nathan & Fiona Upchurch
fields.info: Nathan and Fiona are members at Trinity Church, Exeter, and they have two daughters, Jess and Arabella aged 6 and 5. They try to be outside lots as a family and love to see some of God's character through creation.

fields.name: Jonathan & Jenny Nicholes
fields.info: Jonathan and Jenny live in Bournemouth where they are members of Hope Church, Ferndown. They have two young boys, Aled and Dylan, who enjoy coming along to camp with them. Jonathan is originally from Wales and has been coming to Brynglas camp since the early 90's, initially as a camper and now as a leader.

fields.name: Adam Cooper
fields.info: Adam and Faye have been married for 14 years and they have 3 children, Isaac, Lois and Evie. Adam is assistant pastor at Emmanuel Church, Chippenham and as a family they’ve been involved in camp since 2005.

fields.name: David Pfeiffer
fields.info: David Pfeiffer is the minister of Cheltenham Evangelical Free Church. He is married to Bethan, and they have 4 young children.

fields.name: Ralph & Rebecca Hammond
fields.info: Ralph and Rebecca Hammond are from Penzance Baptist Church, Cornwall, and have been coming on camps as campers or officers for many years. Ralph lead a camp for the first time in 2007.

fields.name: Chungman Shon
fields.info: Chungman Shon is an elder at Hayes Town Chapel, Hayes, and will be coming as a chaplain on camp for the first time in 2018.

fields.name: Josef & Emma De Jong
fields.info: Josef and Emma have both attended CCIW camps for many years as both campers and officers and first met on camp when they were 11! They now live in Kent with their two children, Samuel and Amie. They are members of Emmanuel Church Canterbury.

fields.name: Wayne Harris
fields.info: Wayne Harris is a member of Emmanuel Church, Leamington Spa.

fields.name: Nick & Naomi Woolley
fields.info: Nick and Naomi are members of Gabalfa Baptist, Cardiff and have been coming on camp since just about forever...

fields.special_info_html: Unfortunately, due to COVID-19, camp won't be running this year. The leaders have prepared a short video below:
Unfortunately, due to COVID-19, camp won't be running this year. The leaders have prepared a short video below:

Unfortunately, due to COVID-19, camp won't be running this year. The leaders have prepared a short video below, and some ideas for activities:


Camp yellow activities - lockdown edition

  1. Go one step (many steps) more than Cadair Idris! Climb either 475 flights of stairs or walk 7120 steps – then you will have climbed Mount Snowdon!
  2. Beaver-whacking or bivouacking? In 2020 the year of staying inside we want you to make the best blanket fort possible.
  3. Are you a Chungman’s Chump or a Chungman’s Champ? Can you make a good prop as a Yellow Camp Mascot – we want to see these in 2021!
  4. Try to recreate one of Pam’s tidy meals! Options: Pam’s Pizza night, Pam’s roast dinner, CAKE!
Unfortunately, due to COVID-19, camp won't be running this year. The leaders have prepared a short video below:
